title: The Separation of Friends
full_text:
Long ago, in a village in south India, there lived a merchant named Vardhaman. One day, while resting on his bed, he realized that money was the axis of the world, and that he would become powerful on gaining more money. He convinced himself that even enemies seek the friendship of a rich man. Money makes the old become young, while even the young become old if they do not have wealth. He logically thought that business was one of the six ways that make man amass wealth.
 
Mobilizing all his wares, Vardhaman set out on an auspicious day for Madhura in search of markets for his goods. He began his travel in a gaily-decorated cart drawn by two bullocks. On the way, tired of the long haul, one of the bullocks named Sanjeevaka collapsed in the middle of a jungle near river Jamuna. But the merchant continued his journey asking some of his servants to take care of the animal. But the servants abandoned the bullock soon after their master had left. Joining him later, they told him that the bullock was dead.
 
In fact, Sanjeevaka was not dead. Feeding on the abundant fresh and tender grass in the forest, he regained strength and began to merrily explore the jungle, dancing and singing in joy. In the same forest lived Pingalaka, the lion. Sanjeevaka, content with his new life in the jungle would waltz and sing uproariously with joy. One day, Pingalaka and other animals were drinking water in the Jamuna when the lion heard the frightening bellow of the bullock. In panic, the lion withdrew into the forest and sat deeply lost in thought and surrounded by other animals.
 
Sensing the predicament of their king, two jackals, Karataka and Damanaka, sons of two dismissed ministers, were clueless as to what had happened to their king.
 
"What could have happened to the lord of the forest," asked Damanaka.
 
"Why should we poke our nose into affairs that are not our concern? Haven't you heard the story of the monkey which pulled out the wedge from the log," asked Karataka.
 
"Sounds interesting. Why don't you tell me what happened to the monkey," pleaded Damanaka.
 
"Now, listen," said Karataka and began narrating the story of the monkey.

3-7.summary: A kind bull named Sanjeevaka gets lost in a forest. He becomes strong and happy by eating yummy green grass. One day, his loud 'Mooooo!' scares the king of the forest, a big lion named Pingalaka. Two clever jackals see the scared lion and decide to investigate.
3-7.moral: Sometimes, things that sound scary are not scary at all once you get to know them.

pause_points.segment_text: But the servants abandoned the bullock soon after their master had left. ... Feeding on the abundant fresh and tender grass in the forest, he regained strength and began to merrily explore the jungle, dancing and singing in joy.
guided_questions: How do you think Sanjeevaka felt when he was left all alone?
Was it nice of the servants to lie to their boss?
What makes you happy when you feel sad?

pause_points.segment_text: One day, Pingalaka and other animals were drinking water in the Jamuna when the lion heard the frightening bellow of the bullock. In panic, the lion withdrew into the forest...
guided_questions: Why do you think the big, strong lion was scared of a sound?
Have you ever been scared of a noise? What was it?
What do you think the lion should do next?

conversation_triggers: What's a merchant?
Why did Sanjeevaka get left behind?
Why was the lion the king of the forest?

8-12.summary: A merchant named Vardhaman, obsessed with wealth, abandons his bullock, Sanjeevaka, when he collapses during a journey. Left for dead, Sanjeevaka recovers and thrives in the jungle, his powerful bellows echoing through the trees. This unusual sound terrifies the local ruler, a lion named Pingalaka. Seeing the king's fear, two cunning jackals, Karataka and Damanaka, who were former ministers, see this as a perfect opportunity to regain their influence.
8-12.moral: Fear of the unknown can paralyze even the most powerful, and ambition can drive others to exploit that fear.

pause_points.segment_text: He convinced himself that even enemies seek the friendship of a rich man. Money makes the old become young, while even the young become old if they do not have wealth.
guided_questions: Do you agree with Vardhaman that money is the most important thing in the world? Why or why not?
Besides money, what other things do you think make a person 'rich' in life?
Is it right for the merchant to leave his animal behind just to continue his business?

pause_points.segment_text: In panic, the lion withdrew into the forest and sat deeply lost in thought and surrounded by other animals.
guided_questions: Why would a lion, the 'king of the jungle', be so frightened by a sound he's never heard before?
What does this event tell us about the nature of fear and courage?
How does Pingalaka's reaction affect his image as a leader to the other animals?

pause_points.segment_text: "...Why should we poke our nose into affairs that are not our concern? ..." asked Karataka. "...wise men seek the help of the king to help friends and harm foes. ... What matters is a life full of learning, courage and wealth." replied Damanaka.
guided_questions: Karataka is cautious and wants to mind his own business, while Damanaka is ambitious and sees an opportunity. Which jackal's viewpoint do you agree with more, and why?
What do you think Damanaka's plan is? What are the potential risks of his plan?
Is it always right to get involved in others' affairs if it might benefit you?

conversation_triggers: What does it mean that 'money was the axis of the world'?
Why were the jackals dismissed as ministers before?
What is the difference between being cautious and being cowardly?

title: The Monkey and the Wedge
full_text:
Once a merchant began building a temple in his garden. There were many masons and carpenters employed by the merchant to do so, who would take time-off for lunch every day. One day, when the workers had left for their usual lunch break, a group of monkeys approached the building site and began playing with the instruments used. One of the monkeys fancied on a wedge that was fixed into a partly sawed log of wood to prevent it from closing up.
 
Curious to know what it is, the monkey began furiously tugging at the wedge. At last the wedge came off, not before trapping the legs of the monkey into the rift of the log. Very soon, not able to get his legs out of the closed wood, the monkey died.

3-7.summary: A group of silly monkeys went to a place where people were building a house. One monkey saw a piece of wood holding a big log open. He pulled and pulled it, and when it came out, the log snapped shut on his legs! Ouch!
3-7.moral: Don't play with things that you don't understand, especially grown-up tools!

pause_points.segment_text: One of the monkeys fancied on a wedge that was fixed into a partly sawed log of wood to prevent it from closing up.
guided_questions: What do you think the monkey should have done?
Have you ever been told not to touch something? Why?
What do you think will happen if he pulls the wedge?

conversation_triggers: What's a wedge?
Why were the monkeys playing there?
Did the monkey get hurt?

8-12.summary: During the construction of a temple, a group of monkeys started playing with the workers' tools during their lunch break. One monkey became fascinated by a wedge holding a large, partially sawn log open. Ignoring the potential danger, he pulled the wedge out, causing the log to snap shut and trap him, which led to his death.
8-12.moral: Meddling in affairs you don't understand can lead to disastrous consequences. It's wise not to interfere where you don't belong.

pause_points.segment_text: Curious to know what it is, the monkey began furiously tugging at the wedge.
guided_questions: The story says the monkey was 'curious'. When is curiosity a good thing, and when can it be dangerous?
What could the monkey have done differently to satisfy his curiosity without putting himself in danger?
This story is told by Karataka to warn Damanaka. What is the warning?

conversation_triggers: What is the purpose of a wedge in a log?
Why is this story a good example of minding your own business?
Could the other monkeys have helped him?

title: The Jackal and the Drum
full_text:
A hungry jackal ended up at an abandoned battlefield while in search of food. Here, he encountered loud and strange sounds and he thought "I must run away from this place before the person who is making such sounds gets me". But soonafter, he realized, "It will not be proper for me to run away without knowing the cause of the sounds. Whether it is fear, or happiness, one must know the reason behind it, otherwise there will be no regret. Let me look for the source of these scary noises".
 
Warily, the jackal marched in the direction of the sounds and found a drum there. It was this drum, which was sending the sounds whenever the branches of the tree above brushed against it. Relieved, the jackal began playing the drum and thought that there could be food inside it. The jackal entered the drum by piercing its side. He was disappointed to find no food in it. Yet he consoled himself saying that he rid himself of the fear of sound.

3-7.summary: A jackal heard a loud, scary BOOM BOOM sound in the forest. He was scared but decided to be brave and see what it was. He found a big drum! The wind was making branches hit it. He realized it was just a noise and wasn't scary at all.
3-7.moral: Don't be afraid of things just because they are loud. Be brave and find out what they are!

pause_points.segment_text: Here, he encountered loud and strange sounds and he thought "I must run away from this place..."
guided_questions: What would you do if you heard a scary noise?
Is it better to run away or to see what is making the noise?
What do you think is making the sound?

pause_points.segment_text: Relieved, the jackal began playing the drum and thought that there could be food inside it.
guided_questions: Was the jackal happy he didn't run away?
Why did he think there was food inside?
Was it a good idea to break the drum?

conversation_triggers: What's a battlefield?
Why was the jackal hungry?
How did the drum make noise?

8-12.summary: A jackal, searching for food on an old battlefield, is frightened by a loud, mysterious noise. Though his first instinct is to flee, he overcomes his fear and decides to investigate the source. He discovers the sound is merely a drum being struck by overhanging tree branches. Conquering his fear, he even breaks the drum open hoping for food, but finds it empty. He is content, however, for having conquered his fear.
8-12.moral: Sounds can be deceiving. It is wise to investigate the source of your fear before succumbing to it.

pause_points.segment_text: But soonafter, he realized, "It will not be proper for me to run away without knowing the cause of the sounds. Whether it is fear, or happiness, one must know the reason behind it, otherwise there will be no regret."
guided_questions: What does the jackal mean when he says there will be 'no regret' if he investigates?

pause_points.segment_text: He was disappointed to find no food in it. Yet he consoled himself saying that he rid himself of the fear of sound.
guided_questions: Even though the jackal didn't find food, what did he gain from this experience?
How can conquering a fear be a reward in itself?
What do you think the lion king learned from this story?

conversation_triggers: Why would a drum be on a battlefield?

title: The Foolish Sage and the Jackal
full_text:
There lived a sage named Deva Sharma in a monastry situated far from human habitation, who has amassed a lot of wealth by selling clothes gifted to him by his well-wishers and disciples. Since, he did not trust anyone, guarding the accumulated wealth became a burden for him, and he carried his bag full of money with him wherever he went. A thief named Ashadhabhooti, noticed Deva Sharma carrying his bag at all times and obvously assumed it to contain valuables. He began to plan on how he could steal the bag away from him.
 
One day, the cheat met the saint and promptly fell on his feet and said, "Oh, know-all, I have realized that this life is an illusion; youth is fleeting and all familial ties are like a dream. Please show me the correct path that delivers me from all worldly ties."
 
Pleased with his humility, Deva Sharma said, "Child, you are the blessed one who has thought of renouncing worldly pleasures. Listen, however low his caste is, the person that chants "Om Namahsivayah' and smears holy ash on his forehead, becomes Siva himself and knows no rebirth. I shall accept you as my portage but you must not enter the hermitage in the night because company is forbidden for saints. After initiation, you have to live in the hut at the entrance of the monastery."
 
Ashadhabhooti promised the saint that he would consider every sign from him as a command and carry it out. Satisfied, the saint accepted the cheat as his disciple. Ashadhabhooti too began making Deva Sharma happy by attending to every need of his. But seeing that the saint never separated the money-bag from his person, Ashadhabhooti thought, "the old man is very crafty and keeps the bag always with him. How can I snatch it from him? Shall I kill him?"
 
As the cheat was at a loss to achieve his goal, the son of a disciple came calling on the sage. The visitor invited Deva Sharma to come to his village and perform the sacred thread ceremony of his son. The saint accepted the invitation and set out for the village taking Ashadhabhooti with him.
 
On the way, the guru and his disciple had to cross a river. After bathing in the river and wanting to rest for a while, Deva Sharma took the money bag and pushed it into a quilt he was carrying and told the disciple, "I have to respond to nature’s call. I am leaving this holy quilt of Siva here. Keep an eye on it." The moment the guru went out of his sight, Ashadhabhooti collected the bag and fled the place.
 
With great trust in his disciple, Deva Sharma decided to spend time by joining a crowd watching two well-fed goats fighting ferociously. As blood was running down their heads, a jackal came there to feast on the blood the two goats were shedding. Deva Sharma saw the jackal entering the scene and thought that the jackal would surely die caught between the two warring goats. His surmise came true and the jackal died, gored by the two goats.
 
Brooding over the demise of the jackal, Deva Sharma returned to where he had left the money-bag with Ashadhabhooti and panicked when he found Ashadhabhooti missing. The holy quilt was there but not the money-bag in it. He began wailing, "Oh, trickster, what have you done? I have lost everything in this world." After a vain search for the trickster, the foolish saint returned home dejected.

3-7.summary: A wise man had a bag of money that he never let go of. A tricky man pretended to be his friend to steal it. One day, the wise man trusted the tricky man with the bag for just a minute, and poof! He ran away with it. The wise man was very sad.
3-7.moral: Be careful who you trust, even if they say nice things.

pause_points.segment_text: Pleased with his humility, Deva Sharma said, "Child, you are the blessed one who has thought of renouncing worldly pleasures... I shall accept you as my portage..."
guided_questions: Was the tricky man being honest?
Why did the wise man believe him?
Is it always good to trust people right away?

pause_points.segment_text: The moment the guru went out of his sight, Ashadhabhooti collected the bag and fled the place.
guided_questions: What did the tricky man do?
How do you think the wise man will feel when he comes back?
What should the wise man have done differently?

conversation_triggers: What's a sage?
Why did the man want to steal the money?
What happened to the jackal in the story?

8-12.summary: A sage named Deva Sharma, who mistrusts everyone, carries his life savings with him at all times. A con man, Ashadhabhooti, poses as a devoted disciple to get close to the sage and steal his money. After earning the sage's trust through service, Ashadhabhooti finally gets his chance when the sage leaves the money bag in his care for a moment. He steals it and disappears. The sage, distracted by a foolish jackal getting killed between two fighting goats, returns to find his money and disciple gone.
8-12.moral: Be cautious of who you place your trust in, as misplaced trust can lead to ruin. Also, don't get so distracted by other's foolishness that you forget your own responsibilities.

pause_points.segment_text: Since, he did not trust anyone, guarding the accumulated wealth became a burden for him, and he carried his bag full of money with him wherever he went.
guided_questions: The sage didn't trust anyone, yet he was tricked. What does this say about the nature of trust and suspicion?
How did the sage's own wealth become a 'burden' to him?
How does Ashadhabhooti use the sage's own piousness against him?

pause_points.segment_text: With great trust in his disciple, Deva Sharma decided to spend time by joining a crowd watching two well-fed goats fighting ferociously... His surmise came true and the jackal died, gored by the two goats.
guided_questions: Why do you think the author included the detail about the jackal dying between the goats?
The sage correctly predicted the jackal's foolish death, but was blind to his own disciple's deception. What is the irony in this?
What is the connection between the foolish jackal and the foolish sage?

conversation_triggers: What does it mean to renounce worldly pleasures?
What is a 'sacred thread ceremony'?
Why is the story called 'The Foolish Sage and the Jackal'?

title: The Crafty Crane and the Craftier Crab
full_text:
There was once an old crane that lived beside a lake in the middle of a jungle, who was too old to prey on fishes. Unable to suffer the fangs of hunger, the crane sat at the edge of the lake and started weeping. A crab, that was passing-by, was moved at this sight and asked:
 
"Friend, what is the matter? Why are you not hunting for food today?"
 
"Son, you have correctly guessed. I am feeling guilty because I have swallowed too many fish. I have decided to fast unto death and am not harming even the fish that are within my reach," said the crane.
 
"But why are you so philosophical today," asked the crab.
 
"What shall I tell you? I have heard that there will be no rains for the coming twelve years. Astrologers have forecast an evil conjunction of the planets. As a result, there won't be rains on this earth for another twelve years. All these years we have all played and lived together. I am now worried about the fate waiting for these poor fish and other creatures in the lake. They will die and I will be alone and without them."
 
"Is there no way we can save ourselves?"
 
"At present, fish and other water creatures in other lakes are migrating to bigger lakes with the help of their relatives. Here, nobody seems to worry about the dark future. At this rate, there won't be any kind of fish left."
 
The crab carried this information to all the fish and other water creatures in the lake. Alarmed, all of them came to the crane and pleaded with him to show them the way to overcome this danger.
 
"Why not. There is a big lake not far from here that has plenty of water throughout the year and lotuses always in bloom. That lake does not go dry even if there are no rains for twenty-four years. I can ferry all of you one by one to that lake."
 
The poor fish and other water creatures at once put all the trust in the crane and agreed to be ferried. Every day, the crane would take one of them at a time to a lonely place, smash them against a stone and eat them. He would return to the lake and repeat the trick every day.
 
One day the crab asked the crane, "Uncle, you are taking everyone to the faraway lake and not me. Why don't you take me there today and save my life?"
 
Tired with eating fish every day, the crane too was happy to carry the crab to the lake that did not exist. The crab was happy and mounted on the back of the crane. As the crane was flying close to the spot where he ate all the fish, the crab saw a heap of fish bones and asked the crane, "Uncle, we have come a long distance and I see no lake anywhere. Tell me, where is the lake?"
 
"You are a fool to trust me. There is no lake. Nor is there water. Say your prayers now; I am going to kill you." The crafty crab at once caught the neck of the crane in his claws and tore through it to death. Slowly, carrying the crane's neck, the crab reached the lake where all his friends, worried that the crane did not come back, asked him what made him come back. The crab said, "you fools, that crane was taking all of us to a lonely place where it would smash the victims against a rock and have them for lunch. I found out his mischief and saved myself by slicing his neck. From today, all of us can live happily without fear."

3-7.summary: A tricky old crane told the fish in a pond a big lie! He said the pond was drying up and he would carry them to a new, bigger pond. But he was really eating them! A smart crab figured out his trick and saved the day by pinching the crane.
3-7.moral: Don't believe everything you hear, even if it sounds helpful. And sometimes, the smallest one can be the bravest!

pause_points.segment_text: I can ferry all of you one by one to that lake.
guided_questions: Do you think the crane is telling the truth?
Is it a good idea for the fish to trust him?
What would you do if you were one of the fish?

pause_points.segment_text: The crafty crab at once caught the neck of the crane in his claws and tore through it to death.
guided_questions: Wow! The crab was so brave! What made him so smart?
Why was the crane not able to trick the crab?
How do you think the other fish felt when the crab came back?

conversation_triggers: What does 'crafty' mean?
Why was the crane old?
How did the crab save everyone?

8-12.summary: An old, cunning crane, too weak to hunt, devises a scheme to eat the fish in his lake. He tricks them by pretending to be their savior, warning of a fictitious 12-year drought and offering to fly them one-by-one to a larger, permanent lake. Instead, he takes them to a rock and eats them. A clever crab becomes suspicious and insists on being taken next. During the flight, the crab discovers the crane's treachery and uses his claws to kill the crane, saving the remaining inhabitants of the lake.
8-12.moral: Be wary of those who offer solutions that seem too good to be true. A clever mind can defeat a stronger foe who is blinded by greed.

pause_points.segment_text: As a result, there won't be rains on this earth for another twelve years... I am now worried about the fate waiting for these poor fish and other creatures in the lake.
guided_questions: The crane uses fear (of the drought) to manipulate the fish. How do people use fear to control others in real life?
What are some red flags in the crane's story that might have made a critical thinker suspicious?
Why were the fish so quick to trust the crane, their natural predator?

pause_points.segment_text: As the crane was flying close to the spot where he ate all the fish, the crab saw a heap of fish bones and asked the crane, "Uncle, we have come a long distance and I see no lake anywhere. Tell me, where is the lake?"
guided_questions: The crab didn't panic when he realized the danger. What steps did he take to turn the tables on the crane?
This story is told to show how a trick can achieve what strength cannot. How does this apply to the main story of the jackals and the lion?
What qualities did the crab have that the fish lacked?

conversation_triggers: What does it mean to be 'philosophical'?
What is an 'astrologer'?
How is the crab 'craftier' than the 'crafty' crane?
